title: Schistosomiasis innovations

Dams and disease
More than 600 dams are in construction or are being proposed. Dams and irrigation systems increase the risk of schistosomiasis by creating suitable habitats for snails. Addressing dam building-associate disease risk can benefit communities across Africa.

title: Schistosomiasis innovations
text:
Across Africa, there are over 1,200 existing dams, with 600 more proposed or under construction. However, 90% of Environmental Impact Assessments completely ignore the impacts of dams have on schistosomiasis and other water-borne diseases.
Without proper risk assessment, these infrastructure projects inadvertently create perfect breeding grounds for disease-carrying snails which results in new transmission hotspots that trap entire communities in cycles of poverty and disease.

title: Schistosomiasis innovations
text:
In regions hyperendemic to schistosomiasis, communities need intervention beyond mass drug administration and short-term snail controls. That’s where rice-fish co-aquaculture comes in as biological snail control. Native fish species naturally consume snails while simultaneously providing farmers with protein, additional income, and natural fertilizer. Rice-fish co-aquaculture is a low external input sustainable agriculture system (LEISA). Farmers need only slightly modify their existing fields and purchase fish; no external feeding of fish is required. Furthermore, fish waste enriches the soil and reduces pesticide needs. In high-risk regions like the Senegal River Basin, pilot studies show farmers recoup their investment in year one while snail populations plummet.

title: Schistosomiasis innovations
text:
Integrated Rice-Fish Farming
Rice is a vital staple to feed Africa’s growing population, however, rice farming exposes farmers to schistosomiasis. Rice-fish co-farming is a win-win-win sustainable solution to increase food security, diversify farmers incomes, lower agrochemical use, and combat infectious disease.
